G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as this claim falls within the scope of claims properly brought in the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the apartment at issue is located in Cambridge, Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, every lease or rental agreement is subject to the covenant of quiet enjoyment, which protects tenants from substantial interference by landlords or their agents with the tenant’s lawful use and enjoyment of the leased premises.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.proposition: A landlord’s substantial interference with a tenant’s enjoyment of the premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.support_reasoning: The court expressly explains that “quiet enjoyment” in landlord-tenant law means the tenant’s right to be free from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the leased premises, and it ties liability for breach of the covenant (and the statute) to such interferences. In discussing the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment and G.L. c. 186, § 14, the opinion affirms that substantial interferences with the tenant’s use and enjoyment (here, repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions) constitute a violation of quiet enjoyment, thus supporting the proposition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929)… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Defendant’s actions constitute a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts common law.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that Cruz Management’s failure to correct serious code violations, despite notice, constituted a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment). It relies on both the statute and common-law quiet enjoyment precedent (e.g., Blackett v. Olanoff) to impose liability based on negligent omissions that substantially impaired the value of the premises. Thus the case supports the proposition that similar landlord actions violate c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts common law.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s actions constitute a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts common law.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case squarely addresses G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment) and Massachusetts common law of quiet enjoyment, and holds that a landlord’s failure to take reasonable measures to address serious criminal activity on common areas can constitute a violation. The SJC reverses summary judgment on the § 14 claim and states that if the housing authority failed to take adequate action to remove wrongdoers whose presence seriously interferes with tenants’ use, it may be liable and tenants are entitled to judgment, injunctive relief, costs, and fees. Thus the opinion supports the proposition that such landlord inaction can violate § 14 and related common-law quiet enjoyment principles.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14. There must be a trial to determine what, if any, measures the defendant has taken to remove nontenants engaged in unlawful activity and to determine the seriousness or substantiality of the interference with the tenancies. If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action… then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord can be liable (via constructive eviction/violation of quiet enjoyment) for disruptive noise and disturbances emanating from premises the landlord leased to another (the lounge), where the disruption was the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s leasing decision and the landlord had the right and ability to control the conditions. The court explicitly rejects a strict intent requirement and a nonfeasance/malfeasance distinction, thereby establishing landlord liability for such disruptions when within the landlord’s control.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge… we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: Analysis of liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: The opinion directly analyzes when a landlord is liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 in the context of lead paint, clarifying that a mere statutory violation under the lead paint law is insufficient and that at least negligent conduct with notice or reason to know is required. This is a substantive interpretation of the scope and prerequisites of liability under § 14, so the case appropriately supports a proposition about analysis of liability under that statute.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Drucker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assocs., 37.raw_text: Drucker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assocs., 370 Mass. 383, 385 (1976)
Drucker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assocs., 37.proposition: Common law principles of quiet enjoyment.
Drucker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assocs., 37.case_name: Druker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Associates, Inc.
Drucker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assocs., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns contract and fiduciary duties related to misuse of a restaurant concept and trade identity, and recognizes an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in every contract. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, lease covenants, or the doctrine of quiet enjoyment. Therefore it does not support a proposition about common law principles of quiet enjoyment.
Drucker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assocs., 37.relevant_excerpt: "We think the complaint sufficiently invokes the principle that ‘in every contract there is an implied covenant that neither party shall do anything which will have the effect of destroying or injuring the right of the other party to receive the fruits of the contract, which means that in every contract there exists an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.’"

Lindsey v. Normet, 405 U.S. 56, 68 (1972.support_reasoning: The opinion in Lindsey v. Normet concerns the constitutionality of Oregon’s forcible entry and detainer procedures under the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses. The Court explicitly declines to recognize any constitutional right of tenants to occupy or enjoy leased property beyond the terms of their lease or without payment of rent, and emphasizes that landlord-tenant rights are primarily matters of state substantive law, not federally guaranteed tenant enjoyment rights. Thus it does not establish or affirm a general legal principle of tenant rights to property enjoyment; if anything, it rejects such a constitutional claim.
Lindsey v. Normet, 405 U.S. 56, 68 (1972.relevant_excerpt: “We are unable to perceive in [the Constitution] any constitutional guarantee of access to dwellings of a particular quality, or any recognition of the right of a tenant to occupy the real property of his landlord beyond the term of his lease without the payment of rent or otherwise contrary to the terms of the relevant agreement. Absent constitutional mandate, the assurance of adequate housing and the definition of landlord-tenant relationships are legislative, not judicial, functions.”

Goreham v. Martins, 485 Mass. 54 (2020).proposition: Defining reasonable enjoyment of leased premises.
